ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: How to choose the appropriate statistical test for an investigation; how to use Minitab; how to check statistical model assumptions

Basic stats knowledge. It was a practical course that moved really quickly, but I learned a lot. If you keep up you will definitely come away with a lot of new knowledge about how to understand probability, regression, etc.
A lot of new knowledge about statistics as someone who had never taken it before.
Learned basic statistics, usage of Minitab as a statistical software.
I learned basic statistical skills and how to use MiniTab.
How to use minitab and graph well
Basic knowledge of stats skills.
I had very little knowledge of statistics, so I learned a lot of new content and applications of those topics
great intro to stats knowledge and a great base before going onto more advanced classes
I learned how to create graphs and to calculate probability which is helpful.

I gained a basic understanding of the field of Statistics. I cam in knowing nothing, and now I feel like I have a much better grasp. It becomes especially evident for me when reading papers where they use statistical methods, I am so happy that I am able to better understand them now.
This was my first stats class, so getting this intro was helpful and covered a lot.
application skills
I learned about statistics which helps me in sociological data
Statistics thinking skills, probabilities, MINITAB, logical thinking
Statistics
The basics of statistics and how to use MiniTab.
I learned how to apply stats to real world problems in the life sciences.
I learned the foundation of statistics in all facets

The class is mostly on stats theory and applications rather than on the computer aspect of stats. Youre gonna use a pretty cool software called Minitab to work on Psets and stuff so at least you dont have to learn to code out of nowhere. The stats that we learned is sort of basic level but it goes pretty far in making you understand lots of research statistics and newspaper data that youre gonna see around so definitely a useful class just for being a more knowledgeable citizen. Although not everything I learned is still in my head, Id say the basic concepts and techniques have stayed - and the rest is in my notebook! This class definitely gives you a good base for any stats work you may do in the future.
Basic ways of analyzing data that you would collect in a survey/study.

This course gives a brief introduction to statistics with the key statistics concepts found in any introductory course. This course however requires learning MiniTab and some more complex concepts that sometimes are not found in typical introductory courses.
I learned the basics of statistical analysis and relationships for a variety of different data sets, specifically ones encountered in the social science field.
I gained a solid understanding of the basics of statistics, enough to interpret simple methodologies and do some analysis
Basic statistical concepts and applications
I have learned basic statistics
I learned about basic statistic tests (e.g., t-test, ANOVA, ANCOVA, etc.) and how to run them/why it is run the way it is.
I learned about principles related to introductory statistics, including regression and correlation.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I liked how it was flexible (you could watch lecture online or go in person). I also thought JRS explained concepts super well, and tried to make things engaging and fun. In terms of weaknesses, I struggled a bit with homework assignments. Most times, I got points taken off for not including details that the question didn't even ask for. Moreover, the instructions were vague, but the TFs were exceedingly picky with grading. It made it a bit hard to complete them, as I was not getting anything technically wrong, but was still losing points.

Strengths: Comprehensive introduction to stats; multiple formats offered (in-person vs. live broadcast vs. prerecorded lectures); plenty of office hours offered; grounded in real-life examples, which helped illustrate the theoretical parts of the material
Weaknesses: Slow grading turnaround, which makes it difficult to assess how well you are grasping the material

The psets were manageable, tons of office hours available was super helpful, and lectures were super engaging. Having more in person office hours would be great. Loved the asynchronous option for class.

Strengths: It is incredibly well organized and everything is easy to find regardless of the format by which you are taking the course. JDRS is also a great instructor who explains the content and holds frequent office hours where he clarifies any and all questions. I especially liked that the exams were open-note since I am one to stress over exams and sometimes forget stuff, this made it slightly lower stakes because I knew I could reference course material.

Strengths: flexible format (asynchronous and synchronous options, and recorded and pre-recorded lectures). The lectures were engaging as well given the topic being taught.
Weaknesses: Better engagement from Ed discussion, as there were times where many students' responses were left unanswered

The asynchronous nature of the class is both its greatest strength as it allows flexibility in students' schedules and also its greatest weakness as it allows students (like me, honestly) to completely check out of the class. JDRS is a good teacher, though.

Another weakness is the lack of communication with TAs. You would log on for Zoom office hours and sometimes they just wouldn't be there. I tried to get one of my exams regraded multiple times over a month long period and eventually just gave up.

I love that the class is asynchronous -- I used to go to class at the beginning of the year but found that I learned better by watching the videos. One of the great things about this class is the number of office hours that are held every week --it made p-sets and studying a lot more manageable.  
I feel like often in class there would be a lot of tangents and I would have preferred to fill that time with more complex and nuanced examples.
No weaknesses. The structure is great and makes it easy to learn. Lots of office hours.

Strengths: lots of support available, lectures are clear, flexibility with how much/little you want to engage 
Weaknesses: flexibility of the course could sometimes lead to lack of motivation

Strengths: can be taken remotely which helps if you have 3 lectures back to back like I did, exams did not require memorization of all the formulas, order in which topics were presented was logical

Weaknesses: I hate to be so negative, but this was truly one of the most poorly run courses I have taken at Yale. The professor was very rarely responsive to communication, the rate of TAs answering questions on Ed Discussion (which is supposed to be the primary mode of communication for the course) was extremely slow, the lectures didn't provide many example type problems to use to prepare for exams, it took EXTREMELY LONG to receive grades for the midterms (often 3-4 weeks despite the exams literally being on Canvas and being majorly multiple choice- I've had similarly large lecture courses where exams are handwritten and we get them back within days), the OH schedule for TAs was not correct for a few weeks so it was difficult to get help, there were grading inconsistencies on homework and exams... overall a disappointing experience for a Yale course
can take this class in person or not, very flexible

The strengths are that you can learn at your own pace. A major weakness is that the TFs are not helpful at all, only the student ULAs are helpful. The TFs did not know what we had learned and never knew what I was talking about.

Strengths: This course gives you sooooo much flexibility. You can do things at your own pace, which is awesome. And JDRS is so so incredibly funny. I watched the lectures for enjoyment!

Weaknesses: because there is so much flexibility, it is also sometimes easy to fall behind...
A strength is the ability to take it remotely and engage with the concept. A weakness was the lack of responsiveness from the TAs.
content was fun to learn
n/a

Strengths: Customisable, good instruction, easy to get help
Weaknesses: not a lot of in person help available, confusion after the half way mark with transferring TAs
I think that its set up is great and its biggest strength. It's nice to have the option to either go to class in person or watch recorded lectures. No weaknesses, it's a good course.

Strengths: asynchronous format, office hours, p-sets, JDRS
Weaknesses: sometimes the number of examples in class felt excessive and I found it difficult to stay focused

Strengths: Asynchronous and a lot of office hours that really helped me learn the content better
Weakness: how fast-paced the course was, which was quite difficult for someone like me who had never taken stats before.
great lecturer just a fast class
Strengths: the online format is super organized and the office hours are super helpful (also, there's a lot of them!)
The teacher is energetic and passionate which is nice. The asynchronous/in-class options make it easy to fall off course if you're not disciplined.

The strengths of this course was how accessible it was. All of the lectures were easily accessible from the Canvas page which allows it to be a course that can be taken remotely. There were also SEVERAL office hours held by peer tutors and the professor himself. It was very helpful because all of the office hours were staggered and you could easily attend any because they were offered throughout every single day! The resources provided in this course was incredible and unlike any other course at Yale. The weakness of this course was that I wasn't able to really engage in the course because everything was remote. But overall, excellent course with great resources! Unfortunately, grading was pretty harsh and often depended on who was grading.

There are some discrepancies in the grading of the Psets due to the different TA's and ULA's, which may make the grading uneven across all students. There have also been multiple times when Office Hours have been canceled last minute, or when the instructor did not show up to a scheduled Office Hours.
Pretty solid course with lots of office hours and resources for students, no recommendations.
S: Appreciated the ability to take the class asynchronously W: Harsh gradings on the P-Sets and the P-Sets didn't really match the exam content.
It is a great class for humanities people. I did not go to a single lecture, watched everything online, and had a very flexible schedule. I hated probability, but otherwise, it was interesting.

Strengths: very accessible (recordings for all lectures) and very in-depth notes are available. 

Weaknesses: there were numerous times that people who were running office hours (TAs, peer tutors, professor) did not show up to zoom sessions or would cancel/reschedule them way after they were supposed to have already started. I found this very frustrating. So, just being more on top of office hour times/the communication of those would be a way this course could be improved.

Strengths: SO many office hours and JDRS's hours are very conveniently timed. Problem sets and exams are not too difficult -- very manageable workload. The course worked well for me as a 5th credit.

Weaknesses: Difficult to seek out timely help via Ed Discussions or email most of the time.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would if you need stats, but I also think there are other stats courses that might be better. I am taking the social science branch of the course, and felt like i really didn't touch on anything social science related.

Yes, especially if you need a respite from the pressure of more intense courses. S&DS 103 moves quickly but you are able to view the material at your own pace. The content is also very useful for most majors.

Yes, take this class if you're looking for a good QR. Good lectures, manageable work. I would definitely recommend this course to another student. I am not a STEM person and this was a great QR. It was no calculus so I loved it. You should be prepared to work to keep up with the class and also to potentially do some learning on your own, but you won't have a problem with the class if you just keep up. It was a practical class and I learned a lot. Great flexible class, not a bad 5th credit.

I would recommend this course to another student, especially if they have never taken a stats class before and/or would like a QR credit that will give them a good grade as long as they are willing to put in the time and the work. I think JDRS is an amazing instructor and he's quite fun,  so it makes the class that much better. I liked the accessibility of the course and the fact that you could decide what format to take it in (in-person, recorded lectures, or pre-recorded lectures).
Yes, if you need to take an intro stats course and need flexibility with your schedule.
If its required for your major or you need an easy QR, yes.
I didn't necessarily find this class super interesting but it's good for an intro Stats Class so most likely you will have to take it.
Yes. If you need a QR take it. If you need stats for your major take this one.
Yes, it gives you everything you need to succeed. The exams and problem sets are challenging but predictable for the most part.

I truthfully did not enjoy the course very much, so I would not recommend it as a course I liked a lot, however if someone is required to take an intro stats course, it is relatively low workload and you can succeed as long as you keep up and put the work in.
yes - great intro to stats no matter what your incoming knowledge is

Absolutely! As a humanities/arts student looking for a QR credit, I'm very glad I took this class it gave me practical knowledge that I'll be able to apply in my own field when looking at data. The teaching staff is very helpful, and I appreciated the amount of office hours offered as a student who needed additional help with the material.
I would recommend for a fair QR credit. I did not really enjoy the class but I did not want to take a hard math course and I needed to tae for psych major. If you put in work you will do well.
YES! Take this course if you want an easy but thorough introduction to statistics. Professor JDRS is so funny and explains things so well.
Yes if they need a refresher or havent taken stats before.
Yes
yes if they are interested
Yes. It is very easy to make this course work for you. You can take it online, watch and rewatch lectures, and I appreciate the open note testsreally tests application over memorizing.
This class is great, especially if you take it with JDRS. The set up of the class as a hybrid is nice and it gives you a lot of freedom. Also, JDRS is a great lecturer and teaches well.

I recommend this course to anyone interested in statistics or looking for a quantitative reasoning class. This was not a difficult class; if you use your resources properly, you can get a high grade in this class. However, do not take this class if you are unwilling to go to office hours or talk to the professor.

Yes, especially if you truly want to learn stats and are willing to put in the work to keep up with class and do the p-sets yourself. You get out of the course what you put in it, and as long as you are going to class and doing the assignments the class is interesting and manageable.
Yes.
yes, you will learn a lot

Yes, I would absolutely recommend this course for anyone who wants to be exposed to stats at an introductory level. If you are taking this class TAKE IT WITH JDRS (Jonathan Reuning-Sherer) because he is AWESOME. Depending on how comfortable you are with math it may be more or less of a struggle, but having the chance to work on psets with friends and in office hours as well as the open-note take-home exams, I feel like you should be fine no matter what. Its a course that really places an emphasis on LEARNING rather than just memorizing content or performing under pressure. This course made me realize I probably want to pursue a data science certificate here at Yale. If youre curious at all about how statisticians use data to make sense of the world then this is a class for you!
Yes, take this course! Extremely well taught and gives you a solid foundation for research in all fields. Just make sure to watch all the lectures and not get behind.
Yes, to the extent that it includes useful content for understanding the social sciences and statistical info generally.

I would recommend this course, but it is a lot of work. I would recommend it for students who are looking for a basic introductory stats course, but is willing to put in the effort. For me, I've taken stats in high school before, so this course was not too bad, but if you have no previous stats history, this course will take some effort to understand some of the course concepts.
I would recommend this course to students who want to gain a basic foundation in statistics. It is a lot of material, so be sure to be diligent throughout the course.
Its exactly what it says in the syllabus, if you want to learn stats as a social science major, this is the best way to do it.
If you want to learn how to interpret statistical conclusions and even make your own with programs that you learn to use, then its a great course!
Yes, it is easy and interesting. Easy QR credit.
Yes, it's a good introduction to statistics (coming from someone who did not take statistics). My one piece of advice would be to just go to class--it's really easy to fall behind in this course.
I would recommend this course to anyone who might need stats for pre-med or a QR credit.
